webTitle: Premier League fans rate the season so far. Part two: Man City to Wolves

fields.headline: Premier League fans rate the season so far. Part two: Man City to Wolves
fields.standfirst:
Fans assess the best and worst of the opening stages – top performers, biggest mistakes and the funniest moments
• Part one: Arsenal to Liverpool
fields.trailText: Fans assess the best and worst of the opening stages – top performers, biggest mistakes and the funniest moments
fields.body:
Manchester City

Best performance? By default, probably the 8-0 win over Watford – but we played our best football against Spurs in that (incredibly unjust) 2-2 draw at home. We tore them apart.

And the worst? The 2-0 loss at home against Wolves. Shambolic defending, misplaced passes, individual errors – that performance had it all.

Related: Premier League fans rate the season so far. Part one: Arsenal to Liverpool

Happy with the manager? Despite the three losses, Pep hasn’t done too much wrong – other than the team selection against Wolves, and failing to sign a centre-half in the summer. Lots of City fans will point at Txiki and say he’s the one responsible for recruitment, but Pep still has ultimate sign-off. He could have developed the team more, too: David Silva has played too often; Foden hasn’t played nearly enough.

Why I love … Ederson Not only is he the best keeper with his feet I think we’ve ever seen, he’s a world‑class shot-stopper too. His saves against West Ham and Everton were incredible. How we could have done with him at Anfield …

What is “the City way”? Never being afraid of taking risks.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Vincent Kompany.

How are you feeling about VAR? It’s managed to make everything worse. In its current iteration, it’s an absolute shambles.

Funniest moment so far … Pep’s antics on the touchline at Anfield.

• Lloyd Scragg NinetyThreeTwenty.com @lloyd_scragg

Manchester United

Best performance? Brighton at home. Fast, entertaining – we could have hit them for six if our finishing was better.

And the worst? Newcastle away. We saw plenty of the ball but still couldn’t break down a really average team.

Happy with the manager? We know how Ole wants to set up, but the squad lacks quality and leadership. His next two transfer windows will be pivotal.

Why I love … Daniel James Such a positive impact: definitely the bargain of the season. There’s so much more to his game than just pace.

What is “the Manchester United way”? Attacking football and developing young players. Both are slowly returning. Hopefully Ole will be given time and resources: some Reds forget how dull the football was here under Mourinho.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Sir Alex would get the best out of this bunch, and deal with the overblown egos. As Roy Keane said in April, there are still too many “bluffers”: Fergie would never have tolerated them.

How are you feeling about VAR? We’ve benefited from it this season but it kills the atmosphere. I’m not a fan.

Funniest moment so far … Pep Guardiola’s two-finger dance at Anfield.

• Shaun O’Donnell Observer reader

Newcastle

Best performance? The win over Man United: organised, determined, gritty. Matty Longstaff’s fairytale winner reminded us how magical football can be.

And the worst? The 3-1 defeat to Norwich. It was shambolic and aimless, the antithesis of Benítez-style football.

Happy with the manager? It was hard to have confidence in Bruce after that Norwich defeat and truly awful showings against Brighton and Wolves, but there have been positives, too. And he’s not to blame for our chronic lack of investment in the final third.

Related: Premier League: 10 things to look out for this weekend

Why I love … Allan Saint-Maximin The jury’s out on his end product but he definitely gets fans off their seats.

What is “the Newcastle way”? Fast-flowing, scintillating football with a talismanic striker banging in the goals. We’re a long way from that.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Kevin Keegan: player/manager, ideally. A man who could galvanise an entire city, never mind just a football club.

How are you feeling about VAR? It’s been positive for us, so fine – but it’s hardly been a seamless introduction.

Funniest moment so far … Matt “Radgie” Ritchie congratulating Christian Atsu for a fine interception by booting him up the backside.

• David and Richard Holmes Observer readers

Norwich

Best performance? The win against Manchester City: the obvious pick of a fairly rotten bunch. To think we went home from that so full of belief and hope …

And the worst? A few to choose from, but it has to be the 2-0 home defeat by Watford. The 5-1 by Villa runs it close but against the Hornets we were so devoid of confidence, ideas and belief.

Happy with the manager? Farke has done OK with the hand he’s been dealt. A horrendous injury crisis has limited his options, as did the lowest Premier League transfer kitty known to man.

Why I love … Tim Krul A leader, a mentor to our youngsters and a shot-stopper extraordinaire.

What is “the Norwich way”? Patient, progressive, passing football. The official “mission” is to serve fans and the community, and it does that well.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Darren Huckerby, in his pomp, roaring down that left wing. If you can arrange that, that’d be awesome.

How are you feeling about VAR? I’m fine with the principle but not the way it’s being used. “Clear and obvious” has to be the bottom line and the decisions have to be owned by the ref and not Stockley Park.

Funniest moment so far … Guardiola thanking Michael Oliver “sooo much” at Anfield.

• Gary Gowers NorwichCity.myfootballwriter.com @gary_gowers

Sheffield United

Best performance? The demolition of Burnley: our most complete performance. They didn’t have a sniff and we cut through them at will.

And the worst? The 0-0 draw at Watford was a grind, although the home defeat to Southampton hasn’t aged well.

Happy with the manager? Wilder’s stock just keeps rising. He’s a major part of our great start to this season.

Why I love … David McGoldrick Still waiting for that first top-flight goal, but he’s a dream to watch. His ability to drop into midfield areas and allow other players to burst past him have caused havoc for more than a few opponents.

What is “the Sheffield United way”? Blending tactical and positional fluidity – yes, there’s our left wing-back playing centre-forward – with never-say-die defending. It’s what got us promoted and it’s why we have 17 points after 12 games.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? One of my only regrets is that we never got to see Harry Maguire powering down the wing in Wilder’s side.

How are you feeling about VAR? Even accepting that its decisions are correct, it’s an awful experience. There have been times where I’ve barely celebrated goals because the referee’s immediate signal is something needs to be checked.

Funniest moment so far … Making pundits look silly. We were told we “weren’t taking the Premier League seriously”, that our style would be “annihilated,” and that we’d be “worse than Huddersfield”. So far … not so much. And our reply to Liverpool fans boasting about European success raised a few smiles, too: “Champions of League One, you’ll never sing that.”

• Ben Meakin UpTheBlades.com @bladespod

Southampton

Best performance? A limited pool to choose from. With the benefit of hindsight I guess the win at Sheffield United looks better than the run-of-the-mill victory against a newly promoted side it felt like at the time. An entertaining game (much better than the 1-0 scoreline suggests), a clean sheet and a Goal of the Month winner.

And the worst? Leicester: pathetic from first whistle to last. The sum total of three fouls in the entire 90 minutes is probably the most eye-opening stat. That and the nine goals.

Happy with the manager? He’s playing a mediocre hand pretty badly. Chopping and changing the defence, playing players out of position … if we were to have one whole match with square pegs in square holes, I think we’d actually stand a chance.

Why I love … Sofiane Boufal Genuinely exciting. He’ll take on players, then beat them again just for good measure. Some say that’s frustrating, but with such slim pickings we’ll take what entertainment we can get.

What is “the Southampton way”? Buying bang average players, giving them more money than their talents deserve, and then not being able to sell them on because of that salary. Yeah, this has all gone south pretty quickly…

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? A defender with stature. Van Dijk – if he bothered to put in more than 10% effort this time – or Dean Richards.

How are you feeling about VAR? Perhaps our one success story this season. By my reckoning, opponents have had six goals disallowed. But, quite frankly, nobody should be remotely surprised that Mike Riley is making a complete pig’s ear of how it’s implemented in this country. The staggering arrogance of PGMOL to think that they can do it their own way without properly testing rather than do it the same way everyone else across the world has been using it is incredible.

Funniest moment so far … At Fratton Park, an upset Pompey fan getting involved in a full Benny Hill chase with stewards round the North Stand.

• Steve Grant Total Saints Podcast @SteveGrant1983

Tottenham

Best performance? The 4-0 win in Belgrade. It felt like a new beginning.

And the worst? After a hairline VAR decision had ruled out a deserved Sheffield United equaliser in Poch’s final game, our players let them amble the length of the pitch to score another. Shocking.

Happy with the manager? The run to the Champions League final glossed over the need for a major reboot – but whether Mourinho is the right man for the job is the subject of heated debate. No trophy for Poch but oh, what a journey. We are bereft.

Why I love … Danny Rose Always gives everything. And the fans will never forget that volleyed screamer against Arsenal on full debut back in 2010.

What is “the Tottenham way”? Ah, glory, glory; “doing things in style, with a flourish”. And if we can marry that with some hard-nosed pragmatism and a title or two, then hallelujah! Over to you José.

Related: What makes José Mourinho special? Former players give Spurs an insight | Fabrizio Romano

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Dave Mackay – described by George Best as his hardest opponent.

How are you feeling about VAR? Takes too long, keeps fans in the dark and decisions are still suspect. Whatever happened to “clear and obvious”?

Funniest moment so far … Shortly after posting news of Poch’s sacking, the club website crashed. ”An unexpected error seems to have occurred,” it said. Indeed.

• Richard Barnes @barnesrichard

Watford

Best performance? Not a wide range to choose from, but the win at Norwich being, you know, a win and everything has to be the highlight to date. Not least because it hasn’t (yet) been tarnished by anything that followed. Honourable mention for the draw at Spurs, which deserved rather more.

And the worst? Being caned 8-0 at Manchester City. A perfect storm of unfavourable circumstance, from the early undefendable opener to the fragile confidence of the side, to the ghosts of the Cup final. A long way back from that.

Happy with the manager? Flores was brought in to sort the defence and has certainly done that – if we’re not quite miserly then we’re certainly credible. Three goals shipped in five now, a dodgy one at Spurs and two to free-scoring Chelsea. What we need now is a goal threat. Troy returning will help, with Sarr and Welbeck to come.

Why I love … Daryl Janmaat Has kept his chin up when others’ have dropped. A rhinoceros of a right-back.

What is “the Watford way”? On the pitch there have been many different Watford ways, and more than one successful. Off the pitch it’s defined by representing and being part of the community, and yes, we’re doing that very well.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Some of Luther Blissett’s bloody mindedness up front would be helpful.

How are you feeling about VAR? Tired. “Getting decisions right” has always been secondary to not screwing up the game in the process for me, and the latter always felt likely.

Funniest moment so far … The relative failures of the likes of United and Spurs – though I’d almost rather they started stuffing people to separate out the morass of averageness in mid-table. We need some poor teams to chase.

• Matt Rowson BHappy.wordpress.com @mattrowson

West Ham

Best performance? The comfortable 2-0 win over Manchester United. It looked like Anderson, Lanzini, Haller and Yarmolenko would trouble a lot of teams and we could have a shot at the top six. Sadly it’s been downhill ever since.

And the worst? The home defeat to Newcastle. Roberto was at fault for two goals, poor old Zabaleta got embarrassed for speed by Saint-Maximin and we let Voldemort/Shelvey score. Burnley away was almost as bad.

Happy with the manager? He’s been unlucky to lose Fabianski, but is increasingly under pressure. Is he worth his £8m a year? He needs to deliver some rollickings, find a decent reserve goalkeeper, stabilise a dodgy defence, get Haller firing again, restore Anderson’s confidence and find a role for Fornals.

Why I love … Lucasz Fabianski With every game Roberto plays, Fabianski looks better and better.

What is “the West Ham way”? Playing attacking football, beating good teams, losing to bad teams, and being terrorised by Chris Wood.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? A rampaging Billy Bonds. He’d gee up our side of fancy dan playmakers.

How are you feeling about VAR? There’s no common sense. Refs should go to the monitors themselves. If it’s a case of being offside by a big toe or an unintentional handball that the naked eye can’t see, don’t give it.

Funniest moment so far … Southampton’s chant at 9-0 down: “Manchester City, we’re coming for you.”

• Pete May Author of Goodbye to Boleyn hammersintheheart.blogspot.co.uk

Wolves

Best performance? Man City away, rounding off maybe the best week in my lifetime – beating Watford to get our first win, Besiktas away in Europe and then beating the champions. The game plan was spot on.

And the worst? Chelsea at home. I’ve never seen us look so bad at the back under Nuno.

Happy with the manager? It’s amazing that he’s taken some flak from some Wolves fans after a couple of defeats. He’s doing an incredible job.

Why I love … Raúl Jiménez £30m was an absolute bargain. And he hasn’t even hit top form yet.

What is “the Wolves way”? Under Nuno we’re a team who will compete, stay in the game, and then hit you in the second half once we’ve worked our way into the game. Our second-half record speaks for itself.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? With Willy Boly out, Billy Wright could definitely slot right in.

How are you feeling about VAR? I was in favour, but now have no faith in it being used properly. Plus we seem to be on the wrong side of it a lot so far…

Funniest moment so far … The expression on the Kosovo manager’s face in September when he realised his half-time tunnel rant during the England game had been caught on camera. Like a scene from The Office.

• Louie Silvani ThroughTheThirds.blogspot.com @louiesilvani4

• Part one: Arsenal to Liverpool

Why I love … Sofiane Boufal Genuinely exciting. He’ll take on players, then beat them again just for good measure. Some say that’s frustrating, but with such slim pickings we’ll take what entertainment we can get. What is “the Southampton way”? Buying bang average players, giving them more money than their talents deserve, and then not being able to sell them on because of that salary. Yeah, this has all gone south pretty quickly… Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? A defender with stature. Van Dijk – if he bothered to put in more than 10% effort this time – or Dean Richards. How are you feeling about VAR? Perhaps our one success story this season. By my reckoning, opponents have had six goals disallowed. But, quite frankly, nobody should be remotely surprised that Mike Riley is making a complete pig’s ear of how it’s implemented in this country. The staggering arrogance of PGMOL to think that they can do it their own way without properly testing rather than do it the same way everyone else across the world has been using it is incredible. Funniest moment so far … At Fratton Park, an upset Pompey fan getting involved in a full Benny Hill chase with stewards round the North Stand. • Steve Grant Total Saints Podcast @SteveGrant1983 Tottenham Best performance? The 4-0 win in Belgrade. It felt like a new beginning. And the worst? After a hairline VAR decision had ruled out a deserved Sheffield United equaliser in Poch’s final game, our players let them amble the length of the pitch to score another. Shocking. Happy with the manager? The run to the Champions League final glossed over the need for a major reboot – but whether Mourinho is the right man for the job is the subject of heated debate. No trophy for Poch but oh, what a journey. We are bereft. Why I love … Danny Rose Always gives everything. And the fans will never forget that volleyed screamer against Arsenal on full debut back in 2010. What is “the Tottenham way”? Ah, glory, glory; “doing things in style, with a flourish”. And if we can marry that with some hard-nosed pragmatism and a title or two, then hallelujah! Over to you José. Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Dave Mackay – described by George Best as his hardest opponent. How are you feeling about VAR? Takes too long, keeps fans in the dark and decisions are still suspect. Whatever happened to “clear and obvious”? Funniest moment so far … Shortly after posting news of Poch’s sacking, the club website crashed. ”An unexpected error seems to have occurred,” it said. Indeed. • Richard Barnes @barnesrichard Watford Best performance? Not a wide range to choose from, but the win at Norwich being, you know, a win and everything has to be the highlight to date. Not least because it hasn’t (yet) been tarnished by anything that followed. Honourable mention for the draw at Spurs, which deserved rather more. And the worst? Being caned 8-0 at Manchester City. A perfect storm of unfavourable circumstance, from the early undefendable opener to the fragile confidence of the side, to the ghosts of the Cup final. A long way back from that. Happy with the manager? Flores was brought in to sort the defence and has certainly done that – if we’re not quite miserly then we’re certainly credible. Three goals shipped in five now, a dodgy one at Spurs and two to free-scoring Chelsea. What we need now is a goal threat. Troy returning will help, with Sarr and Welbeck to come. Why I love … Daryl Janmaat Has kept his chin up when others’ have dropped. A rhinoceros of a right-back. What is “the Watford way”? On the pitch there have been many different Watford ways, and more than one successful. Off the pitch it’s defined by representing and being part of the community, and yes, we’re doing that very well. Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Some of Luther Blissett’s bloody mindedness up front would be helpful. How are you feeling about VAR? Tired. “Getting decisions right” has always been secondary to not screwing up the game in the process for me, and the latter always felt likely. Funniest moment so far … The relative failures of the likes of United and Spurs – though I’d almost rather they started stuffing people to separate out the morass of averageness in mid-table. We need some poor teams to chase. • Matt Rowson BHappy.wordpress.com @mattrowson West Ham Best performance? The comfortable 2-0 win over Manchester United. It looked like Anderson, Lanzini, Haller and Yarmolenko would trouble a lot of teams and we could have a shot at the top six. Sadly it’s been downhill ever since. And the worst? The home defeat to Newcastle. Roberto was at fault for two goals, poor old Zabaleta got embarrassed for speed by Saint-Maximin and we let Voldemort/Shelvey score. Burnley away was almost as bad. Happy with the manager? He’s been unlucky to lose Fabianski, but is increasingly under pressure. Is he worth his £8m a year? He needs to deliver some rollickings, find a decent reserve goalkeeper, stabilise a dodgy defence, get Haller firing again, restore Anderson’s confidence and find a role for Fornals. Why I love … Lucasz Fabianski With every game Roberto plays, Fabianski looks better and better. What is “the West Ham way”? Playing attacking football, beating good teams, losing to bad teams, and being terrorised by Chris Wood. Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? A rampaging Billy Bonds. He’d gee up our side of fancy dan playmakers. How are you feeling about VAR? There’s no common sense. Refs should go to the monitors themselves. If it’s a case of being offside by a big toe or an unintentional handball that the naked eye can’t see, don’t give it. Funniest moment so far … Southampton’s chant at 9-0 down: “Manchester City, we’re coming for you.” • Pete May Author of Goodbye to Boleyn hammersintheheart.blogspot.co.uk Wolves Best performance? Man City away, rounding off maybe the best week in my lifetime – beating Watford to get our first win, Besiktas away in Europe and then beating the champions. The game plan was spot on. And the worst? Chelsea at home. I’ve never seen us look so bad at the back under Nuno. Happy with the manager? It’s amazing that he’s taken some flak from some Wolves fans after a couple of defeats. He’s doing an incredible job. Why I love … Raúl Jiménez £30m was an absolute bargain. And he hasn’t even hit top form yet. What is “the Wolves way”? Under Nuno we’re a team who will compete, stay in the game, and then hit you in the second half once we’ve worked our way into the game. Our second-half record speaks for itself. Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? With Willy Boly out, Billy Wright could definitely slot right in. How are you feeling about VAR? I was in favour, but now have no faith in it being used properly. Plus we seem to be on the wrong side of it a lot so far… Funniest moment so far … The expression on the Kosovo manager’s face in September when he realised his half-time tunnel rant during the England game had been caught on camera. Like a scene from The Office. • Louie Silvani ThroughTheThirds.blogspot.com @louiesilvani4 • Part one: Arsenal to Liverpool

webTitle: Premier League fans rate the season so far. Part one: Arsenal to Liverpool

fields.headline: Premier League fans rate the season so far. Part one: Arsenal to Liverpool
fields.standfirst:
Fans assess the best and worst of the opening stages – top performers, biggest mistakes and the funniest moments
• Part two: Manchester City to Wolves
fields.trailText: Fans assess the best and worst of the opening stages – top performers, biggest mistakes and the funniest moments
fields.body:
Arsenal

Best performance? Comebacks against Spurs and with 10 men against Villa were decent. Otherwise, lacklustre. Maitland-Niles being forced off to remove a gold necklace in-play against Vitória sort of sums things up so far.

And the worst? 2-0 up at Vicarage Road. Cue second-half capitulation.

Happy with the manager? Inoffensive, but hapless. Mr Good Ebening’s tinkering is in sharp contrast with how Rodgers and Lampard have moulded their respective teams in their image. The atmosphere is toxic, again.

Related: Premier League fans rate the season so far. Part two: Man City to Wolves

Why I love … Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang Feeds on scraps, but Auba invariably comes up trumps.

What is “the Arsenal way”? I was weaned on a Gunners side where “resilience” was the watchword. These days we’re about spinelessness.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? The Invisible Wall, Gilberto, to stop our defence from being so exposed.

How are you feeling about VAR? Totally infuriating, ruining the passion and flow. If it’s staying, it must be limited to “clear and obvious” errors.

Funniest moment so far … Spurs 2 Bayern Munich 7. Their humiliations have been the only solid crumbs of comfort.

• Bernard Azulay GoonersDiary.co.uk @GoonerN5

Aston Villa

Best performance? The first half against Burnley: we took apart a proper Premier League team. That showed how good our football can be at its best.

And the worst? The first half against Wolves. Leggy, off the pace and leaderless.

Happy with the manager? He’s popular, and learning quickly. Some say he’s a bit gung-ho: I guess it’s game management that needs to improve

Why I love … Jack Grealish Took a few games to get up to speed, but inspirational since. We’ve got the prayer mats out now, hoping his injury heals properly. We’re toothless without him

What is “the Aston Villa way”? The appalling 2014-18 period stripped us of most of our identity. But this young manager and team are trying to re-establish the desire to win with a bit of flair. That said, I’d sacrifice a snazzy playing style (and a limb) to stay up.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Dwight Yorke. He’d provide the link-up play and the goals to keep us afloat.

How are you feeling about VAR? Soul-destroying. It works in stop-start sports; the beauty of football is its flow and momentum, and the joy of a goal. VAR eradicates all that. Stop it. Now.

Funniest moment so far … Karren Brady’s attempts to be a football columnist are consistently hilarious.

• Jonathan Pritchard Observer reader

Bournemouth

Best performance? The away win at Southampton. Accomplished, and our first win at St Mary’s – long overdue!

And the worst? Arsenal away: flatter than a can of Coke left out overnight. We took too long to get going – a familiar problem this season.

Happy with the manager? Of course. If his team could defend better we might have lost him to a rival by now.

Why I love … Jefferson Lerma Not the quickest or the cleanest of players, but he just desperately wants to win. He’s the heartbeat of the side.

What is “the Bournemouth way”? Under Eddie, it’s about playing out from the back and sucking teams in. He likes counterattacking, expressive players.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Nigel Spackman had a great career here in the early 80s (119 games) and went on to play for Chelsea, Liverpool and Rangers. We could do with his pinpoint passing.

How are you feeling about VAR? Put it in the bin. Technology can’t judge issues that just aren’t black or white. A fiasco.

Funniest moment so far … Southampton’s comic defending for our third goal: Angus Gunn and Jan Bednarek running in to each other. Oh, and a certain 9-0 reverse to Leicester.

• Peter Bell AFCBchimes.blogspot.co.uk @cherrychimes

Related: What makes José Mourinho special? Former players give Spurs an insight | Fabrizio Romano

Brighton

Best performance? Beating Spurs 3-0 days after they lost 7-2 to Bayern. We were fearless in a win as impressive as it was unexpected, with two goals for teenager Aaron Connolly on his full debut. The crowd sang “we want seven”.

And the worst? Losing at Old Trafford. In the past we’ve been unlucky to come away from there with nothing – this time we never got going.

Happy with the manager? The transformation has been instant: we’re now creative and exciting. It’s magical.

Why I love … Leandro Trossard A brilliant signing. He missed a few games through injury but turned the match against Everton after coming on as sub, then scored the first and made the second against Norwich. The only worry is whether we can hold on to him.

What is “the Brighton way”? We’ve added style to never giving up.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Peter Ward, to score 30 goals a season, and get us into the top six.

How are you feeling about VAR? I loved it in the Everton game when it noticed Connolly had been trodden on in the area. But mostly it’s frustrating. It doesn’t stop mistakes.

Funniest moment so far … Back in April BT’s Jake Humphrey tweeted: “Having watched Brighton today, and I know I’m not impartial, but you really should be pleased about the prospect of an expansive, exciting, ambitious Norwich team full of home-grown talents joining the Premier League.” Which made beating a dull, disorganised Norwich side at the Amex that bit sweeter.

• Steph Fincham Observer reader

Burnley

Best performance? The 1-1 draw at Wolves, particularly in the first half when we totally dominated against the team that finished seventh last season. Only the softest of stoppage-time penalties stopped us winning.

And the worst? 0-3 at Sheffield United. We were second best from start to finish as the Blades did to us what we’ve done to so many other teams.

Happy with the manager? I’m sure there are things he might wish he’d done differently, but being in the top flight for a fourth straight season is some achievement.

Why I love … Chris Wood Offside too much, but we’re better with him than without him. He makes the pitch bigger, holds up play and runs the channels, and his goal return is excellent.

What is “the Burnley way”? As Sean Dyche puts it: maximum effort, minimum requirement.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Jimmy McIlroy. The most talented player to wear the claret and blue.

How are you feeling about VAR? The worst change we’ve ever had. Someone needs to pull the plug.

Funniest moment so far … Pep Guardiola reacting to not getting it all his own way at Liverpool.

• Tony Scholes UpTheClarets.com @UTCdotcom

Chelsea

Trizia Fiorellino, who covered Chelsea for our Fans Verdict feature for over a decade, died in October after a short illness, aged 50. Trizia was a hugely respected figure at the club, chair of Chelsea Supporters Group, and always wrote with passion, humour and insight. In her last piece, in August, she discussed what lay ahead with VAR, writing:

I want to howl at a referee error, scream at the injustice of it all, become apoplectic with rage at a missed red card tackle; I want to laugh my ass off when we score an offside goal against Spurs, grin like a lunatic when the wrong Manchester United player gets sent off, and guffaw when the ref overlooks a Liverpool stonewall penalty (as if…). The point is, our game is passionate not despite the flaws, but because of the flaws.

Below, her partner of 18 years, Paul Baker, continues Trizia’s work. We send him, and Trizia’s family and friends, our deepest sympathies.

• Crisis, the national charity for homeless people, was a cause close to Trizia’s heart. You can donate in her memory here.

Best performance? Ajax away. We took it to them, and that late winner was just perfect.

And the worst? A toss-up between the 20-minute spell that cost us at Old Trafford and 2-2 with Sheffield United. No home team should surrender a two-goal lead against a newly-promoted side. Or against anyone, for that matter.

Happy with the manager? What a start. We’re so exciting going forward – the crowd are absolutely buzzing. Clean sheets are the issue, but with zonal marking disappearing, and players coming back, that should improve.

Why I love … Mason Mount His willingness to shoot at every opportunity must be something he’s picked up working with Lampard. A proper star in the making.

What is “the Chelsea way”? Never giving up. Season after season we’ve seen lost causes turn into triumphs. The current side is certainly living up to it in a transitional season.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Eden who? Didier Drogba would be the perfect mentor for Tammy Abraham.

How are you feeling about VAR? It has killed the joy of celebrating a goal. There’s too much at stake to call it a work in progress. It needs to be scrapped, now.

Best moment so far … The outpouring of love and respect for Trizia. It has really given me comfort during this sad time. I miss her hugely and my heart is broken – but for me she’ll always be looking down from her seat in the front row of the East Upper, watching her beautiful Chelsea.

• Paul Baker

Crystal Palace

Best performance? With honourable mentions to our first ever win at the Olympic Stadium, where we came from behind to seal three points, and our first league win at Old Trafford in 30 years, I would point to our 1-0 home win over Villa. We absolutely dominated from start to finish, and were relentless. As convincing a victory as a 1-0 can be.

And the worst? Spurs away: desperate stuff. To be 4-0 down at half-time was shocking. What made it worse was Newcastle and Brighton beating them so easily …

Happy with the manager? He’s done very well with relatively limited resources, and no replacement for Aaron Wan-Bissaka, our player of the year. Gary Cahill and James McCarthy were good signings, but his refusal to use Max Meyer or Victor Camarasa to add creativity has caused some frustration.

Why I love … Gary Cahill He could’ve shown up and coasted in the early twilight of his career but has been terrific and led by example. An incredible bargain.

What is “the Palace way”? It used to be counterattacking at pace with skilful wingers, giving the big clubs a bloody nose. But it’s all become a bit more pragmatic lately.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Andy Johnson. Pace, and a clinical eye for goal. What a difference he’d make.

How are you feeling about VAR? It has massively benefited us. No surprise, really, as the so-called smaller clubs didn’t used to get the big decisions. It has corrected some obvious wrongs, particularly the Zaha penalty at Arsenal.

Funniest moment so far … Arsenal’s wild celebrations after their late winner against us – especially Alexandre Lacazette’s full-on frenzied knee slide for the cameras. Cue VAR …

• Chris Waters PalaceTrust.org.uk @Clapham_Grand

Everton

Best performance? West Ham at Goodison. Quick passing combined with good pressing. We should have won by a much greater margin.

And the worst? The home defeat to Sheffield United. Not a single player put in an acceptable level of performance.

Happy with the manager? Silva is an enigma. He’s often dour and uncommunicative, but is highly rated as a coach and well liked by players. He’s tactically stubborn with a default formation of two defensive midfielders, and still hasn’t solved our weaknesses in dead ball situations – though dropping zonal marking may help. He’s been unlucky with injuries, too.

Why I love … Tom Davies A proper fan’s favourite. The local lad is showing flashes of form again, and he’s still only 21. He has the potential to become a proper Everton great.

What is “the Everton way”? As per the club motto, “only the best is good enough”. Sadly, as a team we haven’t lived up to that for many a long year. But there’s always hope …

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? William Ralph Dean: the greatest goalscorer the game has seen.

How are you feeling about VAR? It’s been poorly implemented. The process – visual and audio – needs to be relayed to the crowd in the ground.

Funniest moment so far … Bill Kenwright kissing “tiny” Bernard on the head during a TV interview.

• The esk TheEsk.org @theesk

Leicester

Best performance? Our record-breaking away day on the south coast. I never dreamed I’d see Leicester hit a team for nine, let alone away. It’s a night I’ll never ever forget.

And the worst? We were at sixes and sevens during the first half at Chelsea early in the season – and the draw with Wolves was rusty.

Happy with the manager? Absolutely brilliant. I’d change nothing.

Why I love … Caglar Soyuncu When Maguire jumped ship to United plenty of pundits wrote us off. Little did any of us know our replacement would be better. He’s barely put a foot wrong.

What is “the Leicester way”? As the chant goes, “we play from the back and counterattack”. But Rodgers has reimagined us as a possession-based side, and no one’s complaining.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha gave us the greatest reward in 2016. This current renaissance would be even sweeter if he were still at the helm.

How are you feeling about VAR? It’s needed long term but the current incarnation is absolutely laughable. Why aren’t we using pitch-side monitors? The penalty decisions have been atrocious too.

Funniest moment so far … Maguire’s new side trailing us by a distance with barely a third of the season gone. Seems the grass at a “big six” club isn’t that much greener.

• Chris Whiting clippings.me/chriswhiting @ChrisRWhiting

Liverpool

Best performance? Overpowering Man City. Even when they pressed us hard, we were in control.

And the worst? Probably Napoli away when we lost by two late goals. But we still played better than we did when we lost to them at the same stage last season, and that didn’t turn out too badly.

Happy with the manager? We’re unbeaten at Anfield since April 2017. Klopp’s a tactical mastermind.

Related: Premier League: 10 things to look out for this weekend

Why I love … Roberto Firmino He’s ace, the best centre-forward in the country. Oh, and Fabinho – also ace, the best defensive midfielder, and scorer of spectacular goals, in the country.

What is “the Liverpool way”? Playing the game the way it should be played, to entertain. Also a passion for the traditions of the club, and looking after our own. It was wonderful to see Sean Cox at Anfield for the City game.

Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Terry McDermott. He could dribble, run, pass, create, score from anywhere.

How are you feeling about VAR? Ditch it.

Funniest moment so far … Firmino’s sheepish sideways glance caught on camera in the Turf Moor tunnel at full time following the “Mané v Salah” spat in October.

• Steph Jones Observer reader

• Part two: Manchester City to Wolves

With honourable mentions to our first ever win at the Olympic Stadium, where we came from behind to seal three points, and our first league win at Old Trafford in 30 years, I would point to our 1-0 home win over Villa. We absolutely dominated from start to finish, and were relentless. As convincing a victory as a 1-0 can be. And the worst? Spurs away: desperate stuff. To be 4-0 down at half-time was shocking. What made it worse was Newcastle and Brighton beating them so easily … Happy with the manager? He’s done very well with relatively limited resources, and no replacement for Aaron Wan-Bissaka, our player of the year. Gary Cahill and James McCarthy were good signings, but his refusal to use Max Meyer or Victor Camarasa to add creativity has caused some frustration. Why I love … Gary Cahill He could’ve shown up and coasted in the early twilight of his career but has been terrific and led by example. An incredible bargain. What is “the Palace way”? It used to be counterattacking at pace with skilful wingers, giving the big clubs a bloody nose. But it’s all become a bit more pragmatic lately. Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Andy Johnson. Pace, and a clinical eye for goal. What a difference he’d make. How are you feeling about VAR? It has massively benefited us. No surprise, really, as the so-called smaller clubs didn’t used to get the big decisions. It has corrected some obvious wrongs, particularly the Zaha penalty at Arsenal. Funniest moment so far … Arsenal’s wild celebrations after their late winner against us – especially Alexandre Lacazette’s full-on frenzied knee slide for the cameras. Cue VAR … • Chris Waters PalaceTrust.org.uk @Clapham_Grand Everton Best performance? West Ham at Goodison. Quick passing combined with good pressing. We should have won by a much greater margin. And the worst? The home defeat to Sheffield United. Not a single player put in an acceptable level of performance. Happy with the manager? Silva is an enigma. He’s often dour and uncommunicative, but is highly rated as a coach and well liked by players. He’s tactically stubborn with a default formation of two defensive midfielders, and still hasn’t solved our weaknesses in dead ball situations – though dropping zonal marking may help. He’s been unlucky with injuries, too. Why I love … Tom Davies A proper fan’s favourite. The local lad is showing flashes of form again, and he’s still only 21. He has the potential to become a proper Everton great. What is “the Everton way”? As per the club motto, “only the best is good enough”. Sadly, as a team we haven’t lived up to that for many a long year. But there’s always hope … Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? William Ralph Dean: the greatest goalscorer the game has seen. How are you feeling about VAR? It’s been poorly implemented. The process – visual and audio – needs to be relayed to the crowd in the ground. Funniest moment so far … Bill Kenwright kissing “tiny” Bernard on the head during a TV interview. • The esk TheEsk.org @theesk Leicester Best performance? Our record-breaking away day on the south coast. I never dreamed I’d see Leicester hit a team for nine, let alone away. It’s a night I’ll never ever forget. And the worst? We were at sixes and sevens during the first half at Chelsea early in the season – and the draw with Wolves was rusty. Happy with the manager? Absolutely brilliant. I’d change nothing. Why I love … Caglar Soyuncu When Maguire jumped ship to United plenty of pundits wrote us off. Little did any of us know our replacement would be better. He’s barely put a foot wrong. What is “the Leicester way”? As the chant goes, “we play from the back and counterattack”. But Rodgers has reimagined us as a possession-based side, and no one’s complaining. Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha gave us the greatest reward in 2016. This current renaissance would be even sweeter if he were still at the helm. How are you feeling about VAR? It’s needed long term but the current incarnation is absolutely laughable. Why aren’t we using pitch-side monitors? The penalty decisions have been atrocious too. Funniest moment so far … Maguire’s new side trailing us by a distance with barely a third of the season gone. Seems the grass at a “big six” club isn’t that much greener. • Chris Whiting clippings.me/chriswhiting @ChrisRWhiting Liverpool Best performance? Overpowering Man City. Even when they pressed us hard, we were in control. And the worst? Probably Napoli away when we lost by two late goals. But we still played better than we did when we lost to them at the same stage last season, and that didn’t turn out too badly. Happy with the manager? We’re unbeaten at Anfield since April 2017. Klopp’s a tactical mastermind. Why I love … Roberto Firmino He’s ace, the best centre-forward in the country. Oh, and Fabinho – also ace, the best defensive midfielder, and scorer of spectacular goals, in the country. What is “the Liverpool way”? Playing the game the way it should be played, to entertain. Also a passion for the traditions of the club, and looking after our own. It was wonderful to see Sean Cox at Anfield for the City game. Which figure from the past would you most want to bring back now? Terry McDermott. He could dribble, run, pass, create, score from anywhere. How are you feeling about VAR? Ditch it. Funniest moment so far … Firmino’s sheepish sideways glance caught on camera in the Turf Moor tunnel at full time following the “Mané v Salah” spat in October. • Steph Jones Observer reader • Part two: Manchester City to Wolves

webTitle: Greta Thunberg to guest edit BBC Radio 4's Today programme

fields.headline: Greta Thunberg to guest edit BBC Radio 4's Today programme
fields.standfirst: The Swedish activist will interview leading figures in the fight against global heating
fields.trailText: The Swedish activist will interview leading figures in the fight against global heating
fields.body:
Greta Thunberg is to swap leading the global fight against the climate crisis for the more stressful experience of directing a group of high-profile BBC presenters, after being announced as one of this year’s guest editors for Radio 4’s Today programme.

The environmental activist will take control of an episode of the BBC’s flagship radio news programme at the end of this year, speaking to leading figures in the fight against global heating and hearing from indigenous, frontline activists. Thunberg, who led school strikes around the world, has also commissioned reports from the Antarctic and Zambia, as well as a Mishal Husain interview with the governor of the Bank of England, Mark Carney.

Related: 'The climate doesn't need awards': Greta Thunberg declines environmental prize

The 16-year-old, currently sailing across the Atlantic ocean to attend the UN Climate Action Summit in Madrid, had only just been born when the Today programme began the tradition of appointing public figures to guest edit programmes in the quiet news days between Boxing Day and New Year’s Eve.

This year’s line-up also includes Lady Hale, the president of the supreme court, who is due to retire as the UK’s top judge when she turns 75 in January. She will give listeners a tour of her North Yorkshire hometown and the supreme court, while challenging the audience to “explore the issue of coercive control”.

Hale, a former law lecturer who has campaigned for greater diversity in the judiciary, hit the headlines in September when she delivered the supreme court ruling that Boris Johnson’s government had illegally suspended parliament. She has since been immortalised in a children’s book charting her journey from Richmond to the top levels of the legal profession.

The Turner prize-winning artist Grayson Perry will work with the Today team to examine “stereotypes and conventional thinking” during his episode, while another guest editor spot will go to the rapper and spoken word artist George the Poet, who will report from Uganda and explore issues around identity.

The final guest editor slot will go to Charles Moore, the former editor of the Daily Telegraph, who will focus on freedom of expression in modern society. Moore, who wrote the authorised biography of Margaret Thatcher and founded The Rectory Society for fans of clergy dwellings, has previously criticised the BBC over its perceived anti-Brexit bias.

webTitle: Talking Horses: Altior v Cyrname offers Henderson chance of early blow

fields.headline: Talking Horses: Altior v Cyrname offers Henderson chance of early blow
fields.standfirst: Both horses have bigger targets than the Ascot Chase in the coming months and the Paul Nicholls yard’s November strike-rate is slightly down
fields.trailText: Altior and Cyrname have bigger targets than the Ascot Chase in the coming months and the Paul Nicholls yard’s November strike-rate is slightly down
fields.body:
Thrilling as it is to have a clash like Altior versus Cyrname so early in the jumps season, the outcome should probably not be regarded as definitive. Both of these horses have bigger targets in the coming months and Saturday’s result will have a lot to do with which of them happens to be sharper for this reappearance.

It looks a negative for Cyrname that Paul Nicholls’s horses are generally needing their first run this season and the yard’s strike-rate this month is slightly below its usual November level. Nicky Henderson, meanwhile, is flying along and, although there is danger in such generalisations, it makes his Altior all the harder to oppose.

Related: Cyrname presents threat to Altior’s record-breaking winning run | Greg Wood

Unbeaten in 19 runs over obstacles, Altior is the right favourite and he does seem to have been crying out for this step up in trip.

1.50 Haydock Robbie Power is an eye-catching booking for Bold Plan, but preference here is for Whoshotthesheriff. Progressive in a handful of runs last winter, he travelled strongly until falling two out in a decent contest at Cheltenham last month.

2.25 Haydock The low-profile yard of Noel Williams has never been so hot, so it is easy to like his talented young Breaking Waves, a real eye-catcher when running on into fourth at Cheltenham last month.

2.40 Ascot The terms of this race favour Call Me Lord, who was wiped out by a faller in the Long Walk when last he raced here. Placed in the Imperial Cup under top weight in each of the last two years, he deserves to get a day in the sun.

3.00 Haydock There was more depth to last year’s Betfair Chase, which Bristol De Mai went on to win on ground that was supposedly too quick for him. So it is with some trepidation that the great grey is opposed here but Lostintranslation showed at Carlisle three weeks ago that he is making up into a really exciting chaser. This is only his second try at three miles, which can help him find the necessary improvement.

3.20 Ascot A 16-1 shot when he won this last year, Caid Du Lin is once more available at double figures. But with a strong pace seemingly assured, his yard coming into form and question marks over many of his rivals, the grey could come to the fore once again.

3.40 Haydock There was some support for Moving In Style when he had his first run for Robert Walford at Exeter. In the end, he clearly needed the outing but better is expected from the chestnut this time, with the extra half-mile to suit.
